taxon_text_17_61: The main thallus consists of long strap-like fronds with a single ovoid bladder centrally interspersed at intervalls. The axis is flattenend except round at the base. Thallus is greenish-olive to olive brown in colour, with a discoid holdfast developing several upright fronds with few dichotomous laterals positionend at margins which are identical to, but shorter than main primary axis. Many of the secondary laterals are shorter than the first ones.
taxon_text_2_62: Thallus length is usually 70 cm (up to 150 cm).
taxon_text_18_63: Dioecious, oogamous: single or grouped receptacles as rounded elliptical bodies (5-20 mm long) are produced on short, thin stalks; at maturity colouration of receptacles distinguishes the gender: male: bright yellow, female: olive yellow. Species is fertile from April to June.

taxon_text_17_133: Brown to olive brown thalli of one or more long, unbranched strings arise from a small disc-shaped holdfast. Strings are cartilaginous and mucilaginous to the touch and circular and mostly hollow in cross section. Thalli are covered by translucent hairs when young. With age, the thalli lose the hairs and may be overgrown by epiphytes. Strings generally grow in clusters, float below the water surface and become intertwined.

taxon_text_17_140: The solitary thallus consists of a terete, firm, whip-like frond circular in cross-section and about 1 mm thick, attached by a small discoid holdfast. The surface of the thallus is characteristically slippery due to the outer layer of short filaments. Numerous side branches of similar thickness develop at a wide angle up to second order, giving young individuals a bottle-brush like appearance, whereas in older individuals the branches in the upper part of the thallus grow characteristically much longer than the main axis. Abundant colourless true hairs are present. In a mature stage the alga appears dark-brown to black, while young ones still show a light brown colour. The cortex consists of radiating filaments of rows of 7 - 10 chromatophore-carrying cells ending in a spherical cell. Filaments separate easily when squashed. The medulla consists of elongated cells oriented along the direction of the axis. Unilocular sporangia are pyriform to elongate, 60-100 µm long, and 20-28 µm in diameter.
taxon_text_18_142:
The alga shows a direct or a heteromorphic life history with no sexual reproduction. Unilocular sporangia are pyriform to elongate, 60-100 µm long, and 20-28 µmin in diameter. They appear from May onwards.

Towards winter, microthalli might develop instead of the usual cycling of the upright thalli, perhaps as a means for surviving until next spring/summer.

taxon_text_17_2802:
As the group of endophytic brown algae is hard to distinguish, we only give a short summary here. For details see further reading below.

Endophytic brown algae may appear as minute dark spots, scattered patches to dense felts on host algae. The infection by endophytes may cause other symptoms in hosts, such as holes on infected blade tips, twisted stipes or necrotic and distorted blades. Sometimes the infection may not be obvious to the naked eye.

Usually, thalli consist of an endophytic part of microscopic uniseriate, branched filaments. In some taxa only phaeophycean hairs emerge from the host surface, other taxa show epiphytic filaments up to 1 cm in length.

In german marine habitats the group includes i.a. Laminariocolax aecidoides, L. atlanticus, L. tomentosoides and Laminarionema elsbetiae.

a general term for carotenes and xanthop: a general term for carotenes and xanthophyll pigments, which are long hydrocarbon molecules with terminal benzene rings. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

with a tough texture rather like cartila: with a tough texture rather like cartilage. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).

a cell of an axial filament in polysipho: a cell of an axial filament in polysiphonous red algae (see axial cell). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
with branching more or less one-sided or: with branching more or less one-sided or with unequal forks ( e.g., deer-like antler horns). (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
fat soluble, green, photosynthetic pigme: fat soluble, green, photosynthetic pigments, consisting of closed tetrapyrrols with magnesium. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a eukaryotic super group that is probabl: a eukaryotic super group that is probably polyphyletic and treated as a separate kingdom or included in the protista. the group includes all algae with chloroplast containing chlorophylls “a” and “c.” the organelles are surrounded by 4 membranes. the storage product of most chrysophyta,: the storage product of most chrysophyta, consisting largely of β-1, 3- glucopyranoside units. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
arising from a scar cell or a basal remn: arising from a scar cell or a basal remnant of a trichoblast. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

a group of individuals formed by vegetat: a group of individuals formed by vegetative reproduction from a single original parent. coalescent (coalesced). joined or fused together. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
uniting or merging by growing together. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).

with cells laterally aligned in curving: with cells laterally aligned in curving rows (fig.97b) (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
single-celled and rounded. (source: Math: single-celled and rounded. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

linked together like a string of beads (: linked together like a string of beads (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).

running together; cf. discrete (source:: running together; cf. discrete (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
united or fused. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

a small cup-shaped structure. (source: W: a small cup-shaped structure. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).

primarily referring to lime-encrusted or: primarily referring to lime-encrusted or calcareous red algae. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

having small wrinkles or folds. (source:: having small wrinkles or folds. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

a nodal band in some species of ceramiac: a nodal band in some species of ceramiaceae. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

widely distributed in all or most oceans: widely distributed in all or most oceans of the world. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).

a cell cut off by a pericentral cell (e.g., polysiphonia); also used to describe the epithelium in crustose coralline alga. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
blade margins with rounded, forward-poin: blade margins with rounded, forward-pointing teeth; also having scalloped margins. crisp (crisped). curled up near margins; crinkled, curled, undulate. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).

resembling a crust; said of thalli. (sou: resembling a crust; said of thalli. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).

cells containing distinctive calcium car: cells containing distinctive calcium carbonate crystals; also intracellular biogenetic amorphous calcium carbonate. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
hooded, like a monk's cowl. (source: Bro: hooded, like a monk's cowl. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
wedge-shaped. (source: Brodie, J.A., & I: wedge-shaped. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).

parallel to the surface. (source: Brodie: parallel to the surface. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).

a herbarium specimen kept as documentati: a herbarium specimen kept as documentation for an identification reported in the literature. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
any covering around the cell. (source: B: any covering around the cell. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a ring or verticil of structures around: a ring or verticil of structures around an axis. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
one branch of a whorl or pair of branche: one branch of a whorl or pair of branches of limited growth. (source: Maggs, C., & Hommersand, M. H. (1993). Seaweeds of the British Isles. Volume 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3A Ceramiales.).
with lateral branches arising in a ring: with lateral branches arising in a ring around the main axis. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Fletcher, R. L. (1987). Seaweeds of the British Isles, Vol. 3. Fucophyceae. Part 1.(Phaeophyceae).).
many branches (3 or more) that arise in: many branches (3 or more) that arise in all directions from a main stalk and are in a circle around an axis. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a flat, lateral protrusion of an interge: a flat, lateral protrusion of an intergeniculum; in corallinoideae (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a tangle of drift seaweeds on the shore;: a tangle of drift seaweeds on the shore; also a common name for fucoid brown algae. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
carotenoid pigments that are fat soluble: carotenoid pigments that are fat soluble; reflect yellow, orange, or red light; and contain oxygenated hydrocarbons. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
oxygenated hydrocarbons derived from the: oxygenated hydrocarbons derived from the carotenes, found in plastids as accessory photosynthetic pigments. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
any group of polysaccharides composed of: any group of polysaccharides composed of a central chain of linked xylose residues with other monosaccharides attached as single units or side chains. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
veering to right and left alternately; a: veering to right and left alternately; also twisting. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a motile reproductive cell, either a spo: a motile reproductive cell, either a spore or gamete. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
the structure producing or containing zo: the structure producing or containing zooids. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
arranged in layers, concentric zones, or: arranged in layers, concentric zones, or parallel divisions. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
linear arrangement of four spores in tet: linear arrangement of four spores in tetrasporangium (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
an elongate tetrasporangium with 3 paral: an elongate tetrasporangium with 3 parallel walls separating 4 spores. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the horizontal banding or zoning of orga: the horizontal banding or zoning of organisms in the intertidal or subtidal regions, dependent on environmental and biotic factors. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
see introduction 8.4 (source: Irvine, L.M., & Chamberlain, Y.M. (1994). Seaweeds of the British Isles Vol 1: Rhodophyta; Part 2B Corallinales, Hildenbrandiales.).
a motile reproductive cell with flagella: a motile reproductive cell with flagella. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a sporangium producing zoospores. (sourc: a sporangium producing zoospores. (source: Womersley, H. B. S. (1987). The marine benthic flora of Southern Australia, Part II. Adelaide.).
a sporangium that produces zoospores. (s: a sporangium that produces zoospores. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a flagellated, asexual spore capable of: a flagellated, asexual spore capable of swimming. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
the product of fusion of two gametes, be: the product of fusion of two gametes, before it has undergone mitosis or meiosis. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a sporangium resulting from the mitotic: a sporangium resulting from the mitotic divisions of the zygote giving regularly arranged packets of diploid cells, i.e. zygoteospores. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
a sporangium formed by cell division in: a sporangium formed by cell division in a fertilized carpogonium of porphyra and other bangialean red algae; it is not produced from gonimoblastic filaments. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
a diploid cell resulting from a zygote f: a diploid cell resulting from a zygote formed in a zygotosporangium and germinating into conchocelis. (source: Brodie, J.A., & Irvine, L.M. (2003) Seaweeds of the British Isles - Vol. 1 Rhodophyta, Part 3B Bangiophycidae.).
nonmotile diploid spores resulting from: nonmotile diploid spores resulting from a zygote formed in zygotosporangia and germinating into conchocelis filaments in porphyra and related bangialean red algae. (source: Mathieson, A. C., & Dawes, C. J. (2017). Seaweeds of the northwest Atlantic.).
